<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of call_connection_handler:
```c
static void
call_connection_handler (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
  size_t processed;

  if (NULL != connection->rp.response)
    return;                     /* already queued a response */
  processed = 0;
  connection->rq.client_aware = true;
  connection->in_access_handler = true;
  if (MHD_NO ==
      daemon->default_handler (daemon->default_handler_cls,
                               connection,
                               connection->rq.url,
                               connection->rq.method,
                               connection->rq.version,
                               NULL,
                               &processed,
                               &connection->rq.client_context))
  {
    connection->in_access_handler = false;
    /* serious internal error, close connection */
    CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR (connection,
                            _ ("Application reported internal error, " \
                               "closing connection."));
    return;
  }
  connection->in_access_handler = false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found. The function parameter 'connection' is not reassigned or otherwise modified as a pointer anywhere in the function (no statements like 'connection = ...', pointer arithmetic on 'connection', or passing 'connection' to functions that change the pointer itself). The code does write to members of *connection (e.g. connection->rq.client_aware, connection->in_access_handler, connection->rq.client_context via &connection->rq.client_context), but MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 explicitly permits modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter; it only forbids modifying the pointer parameter itself. The local variable 'daemon' is initialized from connection->daemon (a read), and 'processed' is a local variable — neither alters the parameter. Therefore there are no fragments that require investigation under Rule 17.8.
